Title: EAGER: Lignin as a Sustainable Resource for Hydrocarbon-Like Transportation Fuels

An important future goal in alternative energy research is the development of biofuel technologies that are based on non-edible feedstocks. In this context, the development of resources with reduced feedstock variations that are sustainable and are not based on food crops is a continuing challenge. Equally important is the transformation of biomass to hydrocarbon-like liquid fuels with low oxygen-to- carbon (O/C) and high hydrogen-to-carbon ratios (H/C) as this is required for compatibility with petroleum- based transportation fuels for which future demands are projected to be particularly high.

Among the biomass components (namely cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin), lignin has the lowest O/C and the highest H/C ratio. As such, if it were to exist as a uniform feedstock, it would be an extremely attractive starting material for conversion to hydrocarbon-like liquid transportation fuels. Currently, such a resource does not exist. Lignins that are available are the byproducts of pulping processes, which are complex mixtures with high content of carbohydrate fractions. They have high O/C ratios, and their compositions depend on the pulping process employed.

This EAGER research project will explore the feasibility of an integrated approach to generate a uniform carbohydrates-free lignin feedstock as a resource for generation of hydrocarbon-like transportation fuels. The process that is envisioned will employ the tunable properties of supercritical fluids combined with the dissolving power of ionic liquids. An integrated process is being considered that will also be generating value-added by products which can themselves be a resource for alternative fuels or chemical feedstocks. Among the byproducts are oils and fats which can be a resource for biodiesel; or extractives-free cellulose and hemicelluloses which can be a resource for bioethanol or can directly be used as a pulp source in paper production. The primary focus of the initial exploration is however on the feasibility of generation of a carbohydrates-free uniform lignin source which can be converted to liquid biofuels with low O/C and high H/C ratio, similar to petroleum-based hydrocarbon fuels using mixtures of ionic liquids with supercritical fluids.

The research will generate the key preliminary data pertaining to supercritical fluids and ionic liquid mixtures with respect to their penetration, extraction and modification power of the complex cell walls of plant and woody biomass. New information will be generated on the miscibility of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin in mixtures of supercritical fluids and ionic liquids as well as new information on depolymerization and hydrodeoxygenation of extractives-free lignin. These findings are expected to be also of value in several other application areas such as materials science and polymer modifications. This research project will train one graduate and one underdraduate student in the involved multidisciplinary disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to explore the feasibility of using mixtures of selected ionic liquids with compressible fluids such as carbon dioxide or organic solvents such as ethanol as tunable solvents for processing of lignocellulosic materials.  The solvating power of the mixtures could then be tunable with composition or pressure or the temperature.  A long-term goal of the project is the exploration of the feasibility of selectively dissolving away the cellulose and hemicellulose fractions with minimal effect on the lignin domains. If this objective were achievable, it would offer the possibility of a pathway to generate a uniform lignin source which could then be used for various applications, such as its possible conversion to transportation fuels. A carbohydrates free resource would clearly be a highly desirable starting point for conversion to fuels with reduced oxygen content.  

In its initial phase, the research efforts were focused on the ionic liquid 1-ethyl-3-methl imidazolium acetate, [EMIM]Ac. However, it was soon discovered that mixtures of [EMIM]Ac with carbon dioxide undergoes a reaction which was not desirable.  It was also noted that due to the high viscosity of the ionic liquid, for effective mixing and diffusion into woody biomass, the addition levels of the modifier solvent needed to be high and the mixtures remain homogeneous. The focus was then shifted to mixtures with ethanol in which [EMIM]Ac, and other ionic liquids known for their solvating power for cellulose, such as 1-butyl-3-methyl imidazolium acetate [BMIM]Ac  or  [EMIM]Cl or [BMIM]Cl are miscible in all proportions.

For these mixtures extensive volumetric data were generated over the full composition range covering temperatures up to 100 C and pressures up to 400 bar. The density data were modeled with lattice-fluid type equations which were then used to generate thermodynamic properties such as the compressibility and the expansivity but especially the internal pressure which provides a reasonable estimate for the solubility parameters of the mixtures at different pressures and temperatures that are important in selecting the mixtures for further explorations. The results of these fundamental studies for [EMIM]Ac and [EMIM]Cl  and their mixtures with ethanol have been published in the Journal of Supercritical Fluids (Volume 98, pp. 86-101; 2015).  The findings for [BMIM]Ac and [BMIM]Cl and their mixtures were presented at the  International Symposium on Supercritical Fluids held in 2015 in Seoul, Korea.

Evaluations of the solubility of various constituents of lignocellulosic materials were conducted with bamboo chips as a woody-biomass sample. A unique high pressure vessel with sapphire windows and a magnetically-coupled mixer with a perforated basket as sample holder was developed and used in these experiments. The extractions were explored in pure ethanol, and in a mixture of [EMIM]Ac + ethanol with 20 wt % ionic liquid content. These evaluations were conducted at 120 oC for extraction times of 4 and 24 h at extraction pressures of 35 and 350 bar.  The extract solutions were characterized with ultraviolet (UV-VIS) and Infrared (IR) spectroscopy.  The bamboo chips before and after extractions were characterized by IR, and further by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). They were also evaluated for changes in the cell wall morphology using electron microscopy (SEM).  

At these modest operational conditions explored, the mixtures of ionic liquid with ethanol were more effective than pure ethanol and extraction levels of 25 wt % were achieved for the 24 h extraction in both the low and high pressure trials. In ethanol, extraction levels were below 10 wt %.  Spectral characterizations showed that in ethanol, extracted constituents were stemming from the cellulose and hemicellulose moieties. In mixtures of ionic liquid with ethanol in which higher levels of extractions are achieved, majority of the extractives were still associated with the cellulose and hemicellulose domains. Morphological changes in the bamboo chips as assessed by SEM showed indications of some loss of cell-wall integrity after extractions with ionic liquid + ethanol mixtures suggesting disruption or some level of dissolution of the lignin from the cell walls at these conditions.  These finding will also be published in the near future.

Overall, the results from this short exploratory research which has for the first time explored the solubility behavior of lignocellulosic materials in mixtures of ionic liquid with ethanol at high pressures have been very encouraging. The findings are paving the way for further research with an expanded scope that will include other ionic liquids and solvent combinations and wood (hardwood or softwood) species. Future investigations will focus more closely on the effect of temperature and the mixture composition to better understand the high-pressure dissolution behavior of lignocellulosic materials in these fluid mixtures.
